item.description: Today marks the end of my summer holidays (for the most part).

item.description: During my lunch breaks this week, I figured out how to set up a #musicscience feed on Bluesky.

item.title: Joining BlueSky
item.description: After reading this article in The Atlantic I think it’s time to jump ship on Twitter.

item.title: A Standing Call for Songs to Sing at Music Conferences
item.description: I have always wanted to assemble a small book of easy enough to sight-sing songs for academic music conferences.

item.title: A short reflection after writing my first, little Stan model
item.description: During my postdoc, I’ve resolved to better understand Bayesian statistics. This started a few years ago, when I organized a group of colleagues to painstakingly make our way through Statistical Rethinking.

item.title: MCG Reading: Dynamic models for musical rhythm perception and coordination
item.description: We ended the academic year reading Dynamic models for musical rhythm perception and coordination.

item.title: Receiving a Letter of Recommendation
item.description: If you are reading this, you are either thinking about or have asked me to write you a letter of recommendation.

item.title: A Decade of Music and Science
item.description: A few days ago Amy Belfi pointed out it’s been ten years since we met.

item.title: About
item.description: Hello! I’m Dave Baker and I’m interested in music, theory, and the sciences.

item.title: Why should it have to be elegant?
item.description: One of the best questions to ask yourself (and others) is:

item.title: How Can Music Science Be More Socially Just?
item.description: Today we submitted the transcript of the panel that the Society for Music and Perception’s Anti Racism and Equity Committee organized at last summer’s conference in Portland, Oregon.

item.title: Orgflow 6: Notes on Minutes and Communications
item.description: Being good at organization is a blessing and a curse. It’s a blessing as it allows you to feel more in control of what is coming on the horizon.

item.title: Thoughts from Teaching Timbre in 2023
item.description: I spent the second half of last week in the UK, doing an in-depth dive on spectrograms at both Goldsmiths and Cambridge.

item.description: Last week a paper that Mitty Ma, Emily Elliott and some of my former LSU colleagues worked on was published at Musicae Scientae.

item.title: Monte Verit√† Workshop 2023
item.description: I was fortunate to spend this last week at Monte Verit√† in Switzerland, attending a workshop on decoding musical structure.

item.title: A Peculiar Anniversary
item.description: Today marks a peculiar anniversary. As of the 2nd of February, for the first time in my life, I have been at the same job for more than a year.

item.title: Tips on Scientific Writing
item.description: At the moment, I am providing a lot of feedback on graduate student writing and it feels like I see the same types of errors that I (and I know many others) made when they started scientific/academic writing.

item.title: MCG Reading: McPherson & McDermott 2023
item.description: This week for the Music Cognition Reading Group we read Relative pitch representations and invariance to timbre by Malinda McPherson and Josh McDermott.

item.title: Orgflow: 0. Saying No
item.description: As foreshadowed in the introductory post in this series, the orgflow system is not meant to make you more productive.

item.title: Orgflow: How I Work
item.description: We have introduced a new monthly standing meeting at the Music Cognition Group where the focus is meant to be on how to work.

item.title: SMPC Anti-Racism Call for First Equity Officer
item.description: Last week members of SMPC got an email for several board positions, one of which is the new Equity Officer (a recently converted member at large).

item.title: Summer Consortiums and Workshops 2022
item.description: I’ve have the pleasure of spending the last two weeks traveling for work.

item.title: Some UK and European Resources for North American Music Science Graduate Students
item.description: Last week at SMPC 2022 I participated on a panel that tried to dole out as much advice as possible to graduate students in the field of music science / music cognition as what they might want to do after grad school.

item.title: Personal GTD Categories for Navigating the Day to Day
item.description: After asking Twitter which categories they used to basically “group” together the many “things” in which they have to do, I was mostly met with people (in private) being like “I have no idea even what you are asking”.

item.title: Considering Plan D: Data Science After Academia
item.description: This week I gave an invited talk as a part of the Australian Music and Psychology Society’s Amplify Your Research speaker series.

item.title: Five Books for Your 1st Year as a PhD student in Music and Science
item.description: When you first dive into the field of music and science as a graduate student, you might be tempted to dive straight into your niche and start reading anything and everything related to your thesis topic.

item.title: Habit Tracking Success
item.description: It’s important to invest in yourself, regardless of your employment situation.

item.title: Ta ta, Goldsmiths; Hallo, Amsterdam
item.description: Today is my last day working as a Postdoc in the Department of Psychology at Goldsmiths, University of London.

item.title: Invasion of the 'Non-Musicians'
item.description: At the end of last week Ted Gioia shared a blog post that reminded him of “the STEM-ification of musicology and how desperately we need more interdisciplinary dialogue about music”.

item.title: October Updates
item.description: What’s new this past month? I’ve gone from under-employed to working what seems to be like full time, which is a welcome change of pace.

item.title: Part Time September
item.description: I think I am finally settled into the groove of working part-time.

item.title: App-less August
item.description: I spent the last month trying my best to avoid the scrolling apps.

item.title: The End of TROMPA
item.description: Last Month TROMPA had its 36th month meaning the project is “technically” over.

item.description: Having just completed a few abstract reviews for SysMus 21, I have a two thoughts I think are worth sharing.

item.description: Last month I received a copy of The Routledge Companion to Aural Skills Pedagogy featuring a chapter titled “Understanding Melodic Dictation via Experimental Methods” by yours truly!

item.description: Today’s an exciting day as I signed a contract for my next year-ish of employment.

item.title: Back to Musicology
item.description: Sound the TROMPA After a few weeks looking for work, in September I will be starting as Senior Research Associate on the TROMPA project!

item.title: Begin the Fugue, Part I
item.description: The past few months have been pretty exhausting. On top of all things lockdown and the global pandemic, a little over a month ago I was told that my job was ‚Äúat risk‚Äù of redundancy.

item.title: Begin the Fugue, Part II
item.description: Vocationtional Vicissitudes After existing in this bootcamp space for the past few months, I feel like I am walking away with a very fresh take on what it means to teach in a vocational, rather than a liberal arts setting.

item.title: Begin the Fugue, Part III
item.description: What‚Äôs Next Having coached many people to apply and get their first jobs in the world of data science, I have now seen A LOT of job postings and understand that a JD (job description) is more of a wish list of an ideal candidate rather than a required listing of skills.

item.title: SMPC for Students
item.description: Next week is SMPC!!! I‚Äôm super excited for it (as always), but this year I‚Äôm justifiably a bit more excited because this will be my first experience going to a conference as a member of the Executive Board representing the student members of the Society for Music Perception and Cognition.

item.description: Background Not everyone might be aware, but in addition to living that dissertation life this past year, I have also been volunteering at Toynbee Hall as part of their newly re-started Residential Volunteer Worker program.
